thread.title: Casino mogul Steve Wynn tapped for RNC finance post
thread.title_full: Casino mogul Steve Wynn tapped for RNC finance post - The Boston Globe

title: Casino mogul Steve Wynn tapped for RNC finance post
text:
Google+
By Travis Andersen Globe Staff February 01, 2017
Steve Wynn, the billionaire casino mogul who is building a resort in Everett, will serve as the new finance chairman of the Republican National Commitee, the party said Tuesday.
The RNC announced the selection of Wynn, a longtime GOP supporter, in a statement.
Advertisement
“His incredible career has been marked not just by extraordinary business success, but meaningful relationships with his employees, guests, and Americans of all backgrounds,” said RNC chair Ronna McDaniel in the release.
“He understands and shares the national enthusiasm for President Trump, and will bring his passion for American values, his leadership skills, and his track record of outstanding results to our Finance operation. We welcome to our team a true patriot who is all-in to help us raise the support needed to maintain the RNC’s record level of organizational strength.”
Get Fast Forward in your inbox: Forget yesterday's news. Get what you need today in this early-morning email. Wynn said in the same statement that he was ready to help President Trump’s administration “. . . make America greater again for the people who work hard every day.”
“Our goal is to bring together people of all backgrounds to meet the challenge of making a better life for all Americans,” Wynn said.
Wynn has become a familiar figure in Massachusetts in recent years, since being selected to operate a resort casino in Greater Boston.
Advertisement
The $2.1 billion Wynn Boston Harbor resort casino is expected to open in Everett on 33 acres overlooking the Mystic River by June 2019.
Wynn was among 20 supporters named in December to the finance offshoot of the Presidential Inaugural Committee. He has donated to a number of Republican candidates and causes but also gave $20,000 to the Democratic Congressional Campaign Commitee in 2000, according to Federal Election Commission records.
Information from prior Globe articles was used in this story. Travis Andersen can be reached at travis.andersen@globe.com . Follow him on Twitter @TAGlobe .
